results.title: The American Film Institute salute to James Cagney
results.creator_credit: Bill Foster, Paul W Keyes, American Film Institute and Paul W Keyes Productions
results.brief_description: This series from the American Film Institute (AFI) salutes some of the biggest stars that helped shape the face of Hollywood as we know it today. James Cagney, one of the Hollywood greats, acted in over 60 films. Remembered mostly for his gangster roles and the delivery of the now famous line “You dirty rat”, Cagney’s repertoire was diverse and included comedy, musicals, westerns and Shakespeare. Hosted by Frank Sinatra, this tribute, both informative and entertaining (winning an Emmy Award in 1975 for Outstanding Television Programme), celebrates his career with a top line-up of stars contributing anecdotes along with excerpts from many of his films. Frank Sinatra delivers a wonderful version of ‘My Way’ with lyrics written to honour Cagney. Guest speakers include: Mae Clarke, Doris Day, Kirk Douglas, Frank Gorshin, Charlton Heston, Bob Hope, Jack Lemmon, Shirley MacLaine, Ronald Reagan, George Segal, George C. Scott, Cicely Tyson and John Wayne.

results.title: The American Film Institute salute to Henry Fonda
results.creator_credit: Marty Pasetta, Eric Lieber, George Stevens Jr and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: This series from the American Film Institute (AFI) salutes some of the biggest stars that helped shape the face of Hollywood as we know it today. Henry Fonda is attributed as acting in more than 93 films, over 100 television appearances and 72 stage plays. To celebrate the life and work of actor Henry Fonda, the AFI in this presentation uses footage from over 40 films with introductions from some of Fonda’s celebrated colleagues: Jane Alexander, Lucille Ball, Richard Britton, Gregory Peck, James Stewart, Bette Davis, Kirk Douglas, Jane Fonda, Peter Fonda, Jack Lemmon , James Garner, Charlton Heston, Ron Howard and Lillian Gish.

results.title: The American Film Institute salute to Fred Astaire
results.creator_credit: Marty Pasetta, George Stevens Jr and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: This series from the American Film Institute (AFI) salutes some of the biggest stars that helped to shape the face of Hollywood as we know it today. Fred Astaire whose career as a dancer, actor and singer is honoured here with the AFI’s Lifetime Achievement Award after a career of more than 77 years and a screen career of more than 40 films. This remarkable and versatile actor whose reputation was established in the films made with actress and long-time dance partner Ginger Rogers is joined by his colleagues in a celebration of his contribution to film including excerpts from the films, ‘The Gay divorcee’, ‘Top hat’, ‘Funny face’, ‘Swingtime’, ‘On the beach’, ‘Finian’s rainbow’ and ‘The Towering inferno’ to name a few. David Niven hosts the event with speaking guests including: Mikhail Barishnikov, Cyd Charisse, Barrie Chase, Bob Fosse, Audrey Hepburn, Charlton Heston, Gene Kelly, Hermes Pam, Eleanor Powell and Leslie Caron.

results.title: The American Film Institute salute to Bette Davis
results.creator_credit: Robert Scheerer and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: This series from the American Film Institute (AFI) salutes some of the biggest stars that helped shape the face of Hollywood as we know it today. Bette Davis acted in over eighty films during her film career. Her superior and uncompromising representation of characters are as vivid and challenging to view today as they were when made. Her portrayal of women as a powerful force is recognised here as adding significantly to the portrayal of women in film. To celebrate the life and work of Bette Davis, actress Jane Fonda presents with the AFI a salute to Davis’s career with footage from over forty of her films and introductions from some of Davis’s celebrated colleagues: Peter Faulk, Olivier d’Havilland, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Henry Fonda, Lee Grant, Paul Henry, Liza Minelli, Robert Wagner, George Stevens Jr., Natalie Wood, Cicely Tyson and William Wyler.

results.title: What can we do?
results.creator_credit: Joanne M Mock and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Drugs: the children are choosing”.
The final films in the series looks at three different approaches to communication between adults and young people as they attempt to make decisions about life and drug. Includes scenes with pre-teens, teenagers, and college students. Urges all avenues of communication to be opened. From the series: Drugs: the children are choosing.

results.title: The Pharmacology of drugs
results.creator_credit: Joanne M Mock and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Drugs: the children are choosing”.
The third film in the series presents a systematic discussion of drugs and their effects. Examines all classes of drugs, then urges that drug abuse education focus on the dangers of alcohol and cigarettes with an emphasis equal to that placed on other drugs. With Dr James Fadiman.

results.title: Drugs: The Children are choosing - The Need for dialogue
results.creator_credit: Joanne M Mock and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Drugs: the children are choosing”.
Reports on a conference in which students and teachers have difficulties in communicating about drugs. Finally the frustrations and problems childhood emerge and it is suggested that it is no wonder young people turn to drugs for escape and pleasure.

results.title: The Animations of Antoinette Starkiewicz
results.creator_credit: Antoinette Starkiewicz, Richard Hartley and Julia Overton
results.brief_description: This tape is a compilation of 4 award winning films from animator Antoinette Starkiewicz. Included on the tape are: “Pianoforte”; The animated adventures of an ambitious young girl pianist taken from the simplicity and magic of childhood into the baroque world of the nightclub. Led by a malevolent master of ceremonies into a hot pink pleasure den devoted to rhumba rhythms and erotic boogie, she is trapped, only to escape through the powers of love. “Pussy pumps up”; This is an allegorical tale explaining the differences and similarities of men and women. Pussy has the ability to transpose herself between the opposites, and in so doing typifies the traits of both in unity and division. “Putting on the ritz”; This is a kind of animated tribute to Fred Astaire, led by a tap dancing hero who leads a bevy of beautiful babes through an Irving Berlin song. “High fidelity”; A young girl, an amalgam of Marilyn Monroe and Shirley Temple goes through her the tricks and steps at her disposal to catch her dancing man.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Antoinette Starkiewicz, Richard Hartley and Julia Overton

Led by a malevolent master of ceremonies into a hot pink pleasure den devoted to rhumba rhythms and erotic boogie, she is trapped, only to escape through the powers of love. “Pussy pumps up”; This is an allegorical tale explaining the differences and similarities of men and women. Pussy has the ability to transpose herself between the opposites, and in so doing typifies the traits of both in unity and division. “Putting on the ritz”; This is a kind of animated tribute to Fred Astaire, led by a tap dancing hero who leads a bevy of beautiful babes through an Irving Berlin song. “High fidelity”; A young girl, an amalgam of Marilyn Monroe and Shirley Temple goes through her the tricks and steps at her disposal to catch her dancing man.
description_for_label: This tape is a compilation of 4 award winning films from animator Antoinette Starkiewicz. Included on the tape are: “Pianoforte”; The animated adventures of an ambitious young girl pianist taken from the simplicity and magic of childhood into the baroque world of the nightclub. Led by a malevolent master of ceremonies into a hot pink pleasure den devoted to rhumba rhythms and erotic boogie, she is trapped, only to escape through the powers of love. “Pussy pumps up”; This is an allegorical tale explaining the differences and similarities of men and women. Pussy has the ability to transpose herself between the opposites, and in so doing typifies the traits of both in unity and division. “Putting on the ritz”; This is a kind of animated tribute to Fred Astaire, led by a tap dancing hero who leads a bevy of beautiful babes through an Irving Berlin song. “High fidelity”; A young girl, an amalgam of Marilyn Monroe and Shirley Temple goes through her the tricks and steps at her disposal to catch her dancing man.

results.title: [Roadblocks to communication]
results.creator_credit: Russell Morash, Boston University and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Dynamics of leadership”.
The problem of communication in group discussions and lecture presentations. Sometimes ideas which are perfectly clear to the speaker are misconstrued by the listener. Examines how this can lead to misunderstandings.
